bibl.title: Letter from Frank Standley to Philip Showalter Hench, June 8, 1948

div1.p: Standley informs Hench that there were no additional photographs taken during the International Tropical Medicine Congress. He compliments Hench for his address on Reed.

div1.head: Letter from Frank Standley to Philip Showalter Hench, June 8, 1948
div1.opener:
ADDRESS OFFICIAL COMMUNICATIONS TO
THE SECRETARY OF STATE
WASHINGTON, D. C.
DEPARTMENT OF STATE
WASHINGTON
June 8, 1948
My dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
After a careful search through the photographic
negatives taken during the Tropical Medicine Congresses
and, in particular, those of the Walter Reed Exercises,
it has been concluded that several blanked-out negatives
were caused by the brilliancy of a certain “Pepsodent
smile”.

The above is the only possible explanation for
the absence of any pictures of the event other than those
you already have.

It is certainly regretted that the coverage could
not have been better. However, it was your own popularity
that defeated our purpose. We had planned to make close-
up shots of you and other members of the Committee immediate-
ly after the Commemoration, but the crowd surrounded you
before we could move in.

Regardless of the lack of a photographic record,
the Walter Reed Memorial will long be remembered by all
those present. I, for one, thought that the address you
presented was magnificent. We have had many calls for
copies of it.

Dr. Sawyer tells me that he intends to send you a
selection of photographs that you are sure to enjoy.
Therefore, I shall rely upon his good judgment to meet
your request.

Should you like to see the “inside” of the Depart-
ment the next time you are in Washington, I would be
honored to act as guide.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, Frank Standley
Office of Special Assistant
to the Secretary POR DEFENSE
BUY
UNITED
STATES
SAVINGS
BONDS
AND STAMPS
Dr. Philip S. Hench,
Mayo Clinic,
Rochester, Minn.
